title: 6 of the best pumpkin spiced treats, tried and tasted
text:
When your local coffee shop starts serving steaming cups of pumpkin spiced lattes (referred to as the Starbucks acronym “PSL”) you know it’s that time of the year again.

Indulgent seasonal coffees aside (make your own with Monin pumpkin spice syrup, £5.95 for 70cl, Master of Malt), pumpkin spice also makes for warming, autumnal desserts and bakes. While sweet pastry pumpkin pies are less ubiquitous in the UK than across the pond, Whole Foods UK is currently serving up a delicious handmade version in London stores.

If you have a glut of gourds, make your own at home from scratch (or source Libby’s tinned pumpkin pie filling from Fine Food Specialist, £2.90 for 425g, to make life easier). Happily, UK brands are cottoning on to our fixation with the flavour, and there are a number of other pumpkin spice-laced food products available here in Blighty – not least the New York Bakery Co’s Hallowe’en bagels…

Hotel Chocolat pumpkin pie chocolates

£3.95 for 90g, hotelchocolat.com

A rich white-chocolate case oozes with a convincing, sweet “pumpkin ganache” (6 per cent pumpkin purée) with plenty of cinnamon, almond praline and full cream, topped with a crumbly cornflake lid.

10/10

Bird and Blend spiced pumpkin pie chai tea

£5.90 for 50g, bird andblendtea.com

This Great Taste award-winning Sri Lankan black tea blend can be prepared with milk on the stove or brewed in water like normal tea. It’s cockle-warming and fragrant but made with carrot, rather than dried pumpkin.

8/10

Mozart chocolate cream pumpkin spice liqueur

£15 for 50cl, Ocado

A pumpkin-spice liqueur (70% ABV), made in Salzburg, Austria. The boozy orange liquid is a balance of cocoa, caramel, pumpkin, cinnamon, clove, bourbon vanilla and just a hint of chilli. Like a pumpkin pie in a glass (but sickly if you have too much).

7/10

New York Bagel Co pumpkin spice

£1 for five, Asda (in stores only)

In stores for a limited time, these dense wheat bagels make for a seasonal breakfast or snack, courtesy of dried pumpkin (2 per cent), spice extract and orange peel, with an inviting aroma that plumes from the toaster. Better with molten butter, rather than smoked salmon.

9/10

Poetic License pumpkin spice gin

£37.50 for 70cl, poeticlicense distillery.co.uk

Part of the distiller’s “rarity” range, this limited edition gin (46% ABV) has a nose of nutmeg, cinnamon and pumpkin, giving way to juniper and a faint citrus twist, with a kick of ginger heat to round it off.

9/10

Pip and Nut pumpkin spice almond butter

£3.95 for 225g, Sainsbury’s

An almond, coconut and pumpkin-seed nut butter for toast and smoothies, seasoned with cinnamon, nutmeg, clove and a sprinkle of salt. Very moreish, though a little oily: it clings to the roof of the mouth, and isn’t quite pumpkiny enough.

6/10
